abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory.
            Project sustainability is likely. The overall performance of
            the World Bank is rated satisfactory. Considering the
            important achievements of the project, all due to the good
            performance of the Borrower and the executing agencies, the
            overall Borrower performance is rated as satisfactory. The
            most important positive lessons learned include: 1) The
            project was a success because its objectives were an
            integral part of a broader Government program for public
            sector reform, which promoted more efficiency in public
            services and displacement of the state in business that can
            be provided by the private sector. 2) Project objectives and
            components were well defined. 3) The Government's
            commitment and ownership assured the project's success:
            El Salvador is one of the few countries in where there has
            been continuity in the reform programs, regardless of the
            political party in control of the government. 4) The
            Government's dialogue with the institutions to be
            affected by the project was an element assuring the
            project's success. Among the negative lessons, the
            following were mentioned: 1) The unit in charge of the
            execution of the project has to receive the full support and
            attention of the Bank's supervision missions at the
            onset of the project execution, since project schedules do
            not provide much time for on-the-job training of the unit.
            The same holds for bid document preparation. The Government
            and the Bank yielded to outside pressure by nongovernmental
            organizations and cancelled the feasibility study of a new
            hydroelectric project for future development by the private
            or public sector--although it had been included as one of
            the project components. 3) The Borrower preferred to use
            other sources of funds than funds from the Bank's loan
            when financing one of the components because it viewed the
            Bank's procurement guidelines as too restrictive and
            requiring of long periods of time for drafting and
            approvals. The Bank should discuss clearly with the Borrower
            the conditions for the use of Bank funds and other sources
            of financing, or should not finance components where other
            less restrictive sources of funds are financing the same
            project as co-financing or independent financing.
